image.altText: A young girl wearing a pink jumper holds a piece of bread made from animal feed.

props.synopsis: In Gaza, Maazize is feeding her children ground up animal food and tea made from sticks and leaves, just so they have something in their starving stomachs.

title.children: In Gaza, this child is forced to eat bread made from animal feed and tea made from sticks

image.altText: A large cloud of smoke rises in the distance

props.synopsis: Residents in Victoria's west endure an anxious night, with an out-of-control fire bearing down on dozens of communities.

title.children: Victorian towns under threat as fire burns in state's west

image.altText: A young woman's face in a circular illustrated portal.

props.synopsis: TikTok is turning social media into a popularity contest worth millions, but for some, it has a dark side.

title.children: Holly lives off the proceeds of an online popularity contest. She isn't even winning it

image.altText: Fence with a danger asbestos sign at the Rozelle Parklands as the clean up continues

props.synopsis: Mulch laced with bonded asbestos is discovered at a residential complex in Canberra, as one landscaping company describes learning their products contain the material as "a major kick in the guts".

title.children: WorkSafe ACT identifies 70 cubic metres of asbestos-ridden mulch at residential complex

image.altText: Two men smiling

props.synopsis: NSW Police hold "grave concerns" for a missing couple after blood was found in a home in Sydney's eastern suburbs and a Cronulla skip-bin, along with possessions.

title.children: Detectives searching for NSW Police officer in connection with missing Sydney couple after blood found

image.altText: Construction machines in a shallow tunnel with an arched roof.

props.synopsis: After about a year marooned in soft ground, the machine named Florence is on the move again. It's a relief to the trouble-plagued Snowy 2.0 project, but those troubles are not over.

title.children: Florence is back to the grind, but Snowy 2.0 has a long way to go

image.altText: Dreyfus, O'Neil and Giles standing at a press conference.

props.synopsis: A central problem is that the department's component parts are a bad fit. There seems an overwhelming case for separating immigration, citizenship and multicultural affairs into their own department with cabinet status, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: Unshackle immigration from Home Affairs and give it its own department

image.altText: A general view of Victoria Park, where bonded asbestos was found in mulch

props.synopsis: Widespread asbestos contamination of mulch has left residents of Sydney and Canberra worried, but experts say it does not pose a "significant risk".  We unpack how asbestos causes health issues and what kinds of exposure are harmful.

title.children: What's the risk of inhaling asbestos from contaminated mulch if you stroll through a park?

image.altText: A woman wearing black and wearing glasses talking to the camera

props.synopsis: Lyudmila Navalny says she has been taken to a morgue to see her late son's body. She accuses Russian investigators of “blackmailing” her, claiming they were trying to force her to hold a private burial ceremony without mourners.

title.children: Alexei Navalny's mother says she has been shown his body

image.altText: Julian Assange looks to the camera as he is photographed from behind glass with graffiti etched into it. His grey hair is back.

props.synopsis: The Australian's legal avenues to avoid extradition from Britain to the US are running out, but something in London gave his supporters hope this week, and it wasn't inside the courtroom.

title.children: Julian Assange has been back in court, but it was something outside that got people talking

image.altText: Peter Costello

props.synopsis: Former RBA governors and federal treasurers have warned the Albanese government not to strip itself of the power to overrule the Reserve Bank, but will the government ignore them?

title.children: Former Reserve Bank governors, and treasurers, say the government must not lose its power to overrule the RBA

image.altText: A seventy year old man in a blue and white checked shirt was showered with confetti.

props.synopsis: The counting of votes for the recent Indonesian election continues under the shadow of allegations of structured, massive and systematic fraud, according to the two losing candidates and election monitoring groups.

title.children: Bribes, rice and groceries — the alleged cost of swaying votes in Indonesia's presidential election

image.altText: Taylor Swift flexing her arm muscle on stage. She's wearing a pastel, sequined leotard.

props.synopsis: Whether you rate her or not — and as Swifties know, haters gonna hate, hate, hate, hate, hate — it's impossible to deny that it is Taylor Swift's moment and the best way to share the joy is not to stand back and judge it, but to step in and feel it, writes Leigh Sales.

title.children: You can try to intellectualise what makes Taylor Swift so damn successful, but you would be missing the point

image.altText: A seasoned piece of steak on a barbecue grill. Behind it a small flame leaps through the grill.

props.synopsis: Sustainability is on the menu for the official review of the national dietary guidelines, but the red meat industry is concerned it will not recognise its work to reduce greenhouse emissions.

title.children: Red meat industry questions sustainability 'remit' of Australian Dietary Guideline review

image.altText: Two women stand on a cricket ground looking at a green cap.

props.synopsis: The Tasmanian Tigers women's team is hoping to secure its third straight title when it plays Queensland in the WNCL final this weekend. To boost their chances, players are drawing on the experiences and encouragement of team stalwarts.

title.children: These cricketers once had no score keepers or change rooms. Tasmanian women's cricket has come a long way

image.altText: A listing of a kids fishing rod, with state government branding and booklet, on Facebook marketplace.

props.synopsis: The state government distributed thousands of free fishing rods to primary school kids in an attempt to engage young Victorians in fishing, and while some kids love their rods, others have ended up on Facebook marketplace. So, did the program work?

title.children: The Victorian government gave school kids free fishing rods. Now you can buy them on marketplace

image.altText: Fire damage to a door inside a prison.

props.synopsis: Canberra prisoner George George has been sentenced to three years' jail over his involvement in a major prison riot at the Alexander Maconochie Centre in 2020 which caused more than $1.6 million in damage.

title.children: ACT prisoner who helped start major riot over cigarettes and dessert sentenced to three years in jail

image.altText: A man looks at the camera resting on the stairs.

props.synopsis: An Australian Federal Police officer will not be charged over the arrest of a protester who suffered serious injuries, after the conclusion of an internal investigation into the incident.

title.children: Police officer won't face criminal charges over arrest in which protester suffered serious injuries

image.altText: A person holds a handfull of ground nickel

props.synopsis: It's a roller coaster commodity: peaks that can draw prime ministers and billionaires to town, but troughs that could make your stomach drop. So, can Australia hang on for the ride?

title.children: It's known as 'fickle nickel', so why do some analysts think this downturn is different?

image.altText: A man in a suit walks along a bare military pier, flanked by two men in military uniform, before a cloudy sky and choppy sea

props.synopsis: As Richard Marles plugs defence black holes, and Peter Dutton plays politics over a boat of foreign nationals arriving on Western Australia’s remote coast, the plight of Julian Assange offers a rare moment of unity, writes Brett Worthington.

title.children: Dutton alleges an 'armada' has set sail for Australia, while Labor braces for another border war

image.altText: Tarryn Thomas in his North Melbourne jersey, standing with his arms outstretched on a field

props.synopsis: The AFL has handed Tarryn Thomas an 18-week suspension amidst allegations of inappropriate behaviour towards women, while North Melbourne has cancelled his contract for behaviour "not compatible with the club's or the team's values".

title.children: North Melbourne sacks Tarryn Thomas, AFL hands down 18-week suspension

image.altText: A blue sign sits in front of a large white building with a spire

props.synopsis: Former Bishop Christopher Saunders — one of Australia's longest serving Catholic clerics — has indicated he will plead not guilty to 19 charges.

title.children: Former Broome Bishop Christopher Saunders to deny committing 19 criminal offences, released on bail

image.altText: An older white man with white hair in a navy pinstriped suit smiles as he shakes hands with a middle-aged man of Indian heritage

props.synopsis: Speaking during his weekly audience with British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, the king also said he was gratified to see how his diagnosis had boosted support for cancer charities across the UK.

title.children: King Charles says he has been 'reduced to tears' by public support after cancer diagnosis

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair looks seriously at the camera. Behind her are two men and blue handprints.

props.synopsis: As the coronial inquest into the shooting death of Kumanjayi Walker resumes today, lawyers for former NT Police officer Zachary Rolfe have foreshadowed a series of objections he will raise when he takes the stand.

title.children: Zachary Rolfe argues to narrow Kumanjayi Walker evidence, days before scheduled inquest appearance

image.altText: a dog sits beside a plaque

props.synopsis: Guinness World Records has revoked the title of the "world's oldest dog" it had awarded a now-deceased Portuguese canine named Bobi, as it found no conclusive evidence that he had in fact lived more than 31 years.

title.children: Bobi loses 'world's oldest dog' title after recent death led to investigation into his real age

image.altText: A split image showing an older man in a living room and Julian Assange, standing on a balcony holding up his fist.

props.synopsis: As the world waits for the verdict on whether the WikiLeaks founder will be extradited to the US, his father John Shipton says Australia should consider imposing "not too brutal" restrictions on our allies.

title.children: Assange's father says it's time to put 'serious' pressure on UK, US to bring home 'son of the Australian soil'

image.altText: Fans in costume line in a queue to buy merchandise with a black 'Taylor Swift The Eras Tour' sign

props.synopsis: Swifties are paying exorbitant prices for hotel beds as some Airbnb hosts cancel last minute in Sydney.

title.children: Airbnb hosts cancelling bookings from Taylor Swift fans at last minute

image.altText: A toddler sitting on the ground cuddling a white unicorn toy.

props.synopsis: Queenslanders are suffering in record numbers from gastro as they seek respite from the summer heat in pools and waterparks.

title.children: Worst pool parasite outbreak in decades puts Queensland children in hospital

image.altText: A humpback whale and her calf swimming through blue waters.

props.synopsis: Whales sing loud enough that their songs travel through the ocean, but the mechanics of how they vocalise has been a mystery. Scientists now think they have an idea, and it's something not seen in other animals.

title.children: How do whales sing? Scientists may have figured it out at last

image.altText: A woman in a field of rice

props.synopsis: Alarm bells are ringing in NSW after the fungal disease Rice Blast was identified in crops in the state's north, with authorities moving to prevent it spreading to major growing regions further south.

title.children: Growers to destroy crops as rice blast fungal disease is found near Lismore

image.altText: A ship pulls Taipan wreckage from the ocean, authorities are in a smaller watercraft nearby

props.synopsis: The fatal crash off the coast of Queensland last year killed four defence personnel.

title.children: Independent inquiry launched into fatal Taipan army helicopter crash

subjects.title: Air and Space Accidents and Incidents

image.altText: Portrait of a man with a weathered face, short hair, neat beard, standing on a sunny property lined with trees.

props.synopsis: The trial will hear arguments as to whether every change to the physical landscape constitutes damage to an Aboriginal spiritual site.

title.children: WA man on trial for alleged breach of Aboriginal heritage laws

image.altText: Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson stands in front of a Qantas plane in a hanger, with the Flying Kangaroo logo prominently visible.

props.synopsis: Qantas has recorded a 13 per cent fall in its post-tax profit to $873 million in the six months to December 2023, largely driven by lower airfares as its capacity returns to normal after the COVID-19 pandemic.

title.children: 'The journey will take time': Qantas boss promises improved service as airfares, profits fall

image.altText: A large warship sails towards the camera through open waters.

props.synopsis: Getting in early with cutting-edge and developmental military programs can yield huge benefits, and involves expensive gambles, but recent global events have shown the option of deploying surface vessels without humans could prove invaluable, writes Andrew Greene.

title.children: Australia could get the world's most expensive anti-sub warship, but the numbers are as complex as shipbuilding

image.altText: Toutai Kefu on a sporting field.

props.synopsis: One of the youngest teenagers involved in the violent home invasion of rugby union great Toutai Kefu and his family was on bail at the time, and went on to commit more break-ins, a court hears.

title.children: Teen involved in 'dreadful' home invasion of former Wallabies star was on bail at the time
